wiki.content: According to the Saint James Infirmary Songfacts, the song is based on an old English tune, "The Unfortunate Rake," that made its way over to America. The song's title is derived from St. James Hospital in London, a religious foundation for the treatment of leprosy. It was closed in 1532 when Henry VIII acquired the land to build St. James Palace. The lyrics tell the tale of a man explaining to the singer/narrator, at a bar, how he went down to St. James Infirmary and tragically found his girl (the so-called "baby") dead. User-contributed text is available under the Creative Commons By-SA License and may also be available under the GNU FDL.

track.name: St. James Infirmary
comments: So many recognisable influences in there.
this song isn't 1:48! it's 6:23 and all of that 6:23 must be heard [3]
this song isn't 1:48! it's 6:23 and all of that 6:23 must be heard [2]
this song isn't 1:48! it's 6:23 and all of that 6:23 must be heard
If this is Hugh Laurie singing then why does he have an american accent? This is House singing.
Is it me, or does he really make the persona sound more like a satisfied killer, who got rid of his (presumably) cheating 'baby' - instead of a mourner?
What a talented pianist he is.
Great intro. Great music. Hugh is so good.
Doctor House this, Doctor House that... Doctor House DOES NOT SING on this album! Hugh Laurie DOES!
